current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to establish within the Environmental Protection
			 Agency a Columbia River Basin Restoration Program.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Environment and Public Works

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Columbia River Basin Restoration Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Columbia River Basin Restoration Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
the Columbia River is the largest river in the Pacific Northwest by volume;

the river is 1,253 miles long, with a drainage basin that includes 259,000 square miles, extending
			 to 7 States and British Columbia, Canada, and including all or part of—
multiple national parks;
components of the National Wilderness Preservation System;
National Monuments;
National Scenic Areas;
National Recreation Areas;
other areas managed for conservation; and
multiple tribal reservations and over 45,000,000 acres of tribally comanaged land;

quote.#tail:
) provide significant ecological and economic benefits to the Pacific Northwest and the entire
			 United States;

text.#text: the Columbia River Basin and associated tributaries (referred to in this Act as the

traditionally, the Basin includes more than 6,000,000 acres of irrigated agricultural land and
			 produces more hydroelectric power than any other North American river;

significant commerce takes place on the federally authorized Columbia Snake River System navigation
			 channel, which is 465 miles in length, from the mouth of the Columbia
			 River
			 to Lewiston, Idaho;
the Basin—

historically constituted the largest salmon-producing river system in the world, with annual
			 returns peaking at as many as 16,000,000 fish; and
as of the date of enactment of this Act—
supports economically important commercial and recreational fisheries;
supports treaty tribal fisheries;

is home to numerous species of salmonids, including steelhead, bull trout, and Kootenai white
			 sturgeon, that are listed as threatened species or
			 endangered species under the

is a cultural and historical resource and provides sports and recreation opportunities for millions
			 annually;

toxics are present throughout the Columbia River Basin that are harmful to humans, fish, and
			 wildlife;

studies have shown that Columbia River fish contain a wide array of
			 contaminants;
in 1995, the lower river and estuary was designated an

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 because of degradation and contamination in
			 the lower river, lack of structure to coordinate programs and policies, 
			 significance of the lower river to survival of species throughout the
			 basin, and the importance the lower river to the economic viability of the
			 region; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a Columbia River Basin
			 Restoration Program for the purposes of reducing toxic contamination and
			 cleaning up contaminated sites throughout the Columbia River Basin.

text.#text: The

The Program shall not modify any legal or regulatory authority or program in effect as of the date
			 of enactment of this section, including the roles of Federal agencies in
			 the Columbia River Basin.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
representing the Federal Government, State, tribal, and
			 local governments, industry, and nongovernmental organizations, which was
			 convened in 2005 to develop a collaborative toxic contamination reduction
			 approach for the Columbia River Basin;

text.#text: build on the work and collaborative structure of the existing

in the Lower Columbia River Basin and Estuary, build on the work and collaborative structure of the
			 Estuary Partnership;

coordinate with other efforts, including activities of other Federal agencies in the Columbia River
			 Basin, to avoid duplicating activities or functions; and
not impede implementation of existing agreements or other recovery and mitigation programs.
The Program shall—

The Program shall consist of a collaborative stakeholder-based program for reducing toxic
			 contamination throughout the Columbia River Basin.
The

assess trends in water quality and toxic contamination or toxics reduction, including trends that
			 affect uses of the water of the Columbia River Basin;

collect, characterize, and assess data on toxics and water quality to identify possible causes of

each State located in whole or in part within the Columbia River Basin;

nongovernmental organizations that have a presence in the Columbia River Basin;
the general public in the Columbia River Basin; and
the Estuary Partnership.
